problem.p: This is a concept question, provided to check your understanding of the previous video clip.
Check all the following which are true about [mathjaxinline][n, k, d][/mathjaxinline] classical linear codes:

choice.text: [mathjaxinline]k[/mathjaxinline] is the number of bits used to encode the [mathjaxinline]n[/mathjaxinline] bits of information.
[mathjaxinline]n[/mathjaxinline] is the number of bits used to encode [mathjaxinline]k[/mathjaxinline] bits of information.
[mathjaxinline]d[/mathjaxinline] is the number of errors which the code can correct.
[mathjaxinline]t=\lfloor (d-1)/2 \rfloor[/mathjaxinline] is the number of errors which the code can correct.
When the generator matrix [mathjaxinline]G[/mathjaxinline] is expressed as an [mathjaxinline]n\times k[/mathjaxinline] matrix, each column is a codeword.
